Type.Name: PaddingMode

TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi serializable sealed PaddingMode extends System.Enum

Type.ThreadSafetyStatement: Gtk# is thread aware, but not thread safe; See the <link location="node:gtk-sharp/programming/threads">Gtk# Thread Programming</link> for details.

remarks.para: Most plain text messages do not consist of a number of bytes that completely fill blocks. Often, there are not enough bytes to fill the last block. When this happens, a padding string is added to the text. For example, if the block length is 64 bits and the last block contains only 40 bits, 24 bits of padding are added.

Some encryption standards specify a particular padding scheme. The following example shows how these modes work. Given a blocklength of 8, a data length of 9, the number of padding octets equal to 7, and the data equal to FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF:
Data: FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF
X923 padding: FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF 00 00 00 00 00 00 07
PKCS7 padding: FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF 07 07 07 07 07 07 07
ISO10126 padding: FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF 7D 2A 75 EF F8 EF 07

summary.para: Specifies the type of padding to apply when the message data block is shorter than the full number of bytes needed for a cryptographic operation.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Cryptography.PaddingMode ANSIX923 = int32(4)

remarks.para: The following example shows how this mode works. Given a blocklength of 8, a data length of 9, the number of padding octets equal to 7, and the data equal to FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF:
Data: FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF
X923 padding: FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF 00 00 00 00 00 00 07

summary.para: The ANSIX923 padding string consists of a sequence of bytes filled with zeros before the length.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Cryptography.PaddingMode ISO10126 = int32(5)

remarks.para: The following example shows how this mode works. Given a blocklength of 8, a data length of 9, the number of padding octets equal to 7, and the data equal to FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF:
Data: FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF
ISO10126 padding: FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF 7D 2A 75 EF F8 EF 07

summary.para: The ISO10126 padding string consists of random data before the length.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Cryptography.PaddingMode None = int32(1)
.field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Cryptography.PaddingMode PKCS7 = int32(2)

remarks.para: The following example shows how these modes work. Given a blocklength of 8, a data length of 9, the number of padding octets equal to 7, and the data equal to FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF:
Data: FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF
PKCS7 padding: FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF FF 07 07 07 07 07 07 07

summary.para: The PKCS #7 padding string consists of a sequence of bytes, each of which is equal to the total number of padding bytes added.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Cryptography.PaddingMode Zeros = int32(3)

summary.para: The padding string consists of bytes set to zero.
